- The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through their chosen representatives.
- The NLRA aims to mitigate labor-related obstructions to commerce by encouraging collective bargaining.
- The NLRA applies to "employees," not all individuals employed by an employer.
- An employee is considered a supervisor if they hold the authority to perform any one of 12 specified functions, exercise independent judgment, and act in the employer's interest.
- In Kentucky River Community Care, the U.S. Supreme Court established a three-part test for determining supervisory status: holding the authority to engage in a supervisory function, exercising independent judgment, and acting in the employer's interest.
- Section 8(a)(1) and 8(b)(1)(A) of the NLRA prohibit employers and unions from interfering with employees' rights to engage in collective bargaining and other protected activities.
- Employers and unions are prohibited from using or threatening violence, coercing employees, or making verbal threats to adversely affect employment status or working conditions.
- The NLRA allows employers to communicate their views about unionism to employees, but such communications must not contain threats or promises.

</summary>

<summary>

- Itemized deductions are claimed by 30% of tax filers, with higher-income filers claiming a larger average sum. In 2014, 91-93% of filers with AGI over $200,000 itemized, compared to 77% of filers with AGI between $100,000 and $200,000 and 5% of filers with AGI less than $20,000.
- Specific deductions, such as charitable gifts, state and local income taxes, and real estate property taxes, are claimed at different rates by tax filers in different income ranges. For example, charitable gifts were claimed by 37% of filers with AGI between $50,000 and $100,000, 68% of filers with AGI between $100,000 and $200,000, and over 86% of filers in each income range over $200,000.
- The largest single deduction, by amount, claimed by tax filers with an AGI less than $500,000 (aside from medical expenses) is the mortgage interest deduction. The largest average deduction amount claimed for any deduction by tax filers with an AGI greater than $500,000 (aside from medical expenses) is the deduction for state and local income taxes.
- The four itemized deductions projected to contribute most to tax expenditures in FY2018 are the deduction for state and local income or sales taxes, home mortgage interest, charitable gifts, and real estate taxes, accounting for 17.8% ($241.2 billion) of the approximately $1.36 trillion in net individual tax expenditures.
</summary>

<summary>
• The AMT is an alternative tax calculation with a broader tax base that requires individuals to add back certain provisions and pay a higher tax rate.
• The number of taxpayers subject to the AMT has increased significantly due to inflation and the elimination of certain tax provisions, and is projected to continue growing.
• The AMT does not index its exemptions to inflation, unlike the rest of the income tax, which has led to an increase in the percentage of taxpayers affected.
• The AMT does not include certain provisions, such as the benefits of lower capital gains tax rates and the exclusion for tax-exempt bonds, which can result in higher tax liability for some taxpayers.
• The cost of correcting the AMT, including indexing exemptions and eliminating credit limits, is significant and would require substantial revenue.
</summary>

<summary>
• The THUD Appropriations Subcommittees in the House and Senate are responsible for drafting bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT), the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and six related agencies.
• Title I of the THUD appropriations bill primarily funds DOT, which is a grant-making and regulatory organization with programs organized by mode of transportation. Title II funds HUD, which primarily addresses housing problems for low-income households and special needs populations. Title III funds various transportation and housing-related agencies.
• The THUD bill includes both discretionary and mandatory funding. Discretionary funding is allocated annually by the appropriations committees, while mandatory funding is based on trust fund resources. The bill also includes provisions for emergency appropriations and offsetting receipts.
</summary>

• Low farm milk prices and declining dairy farm incomes in 2009 led to renewed interest in imposing import barriers on milk protein concentrates (MPCs) to prevent unlimited importation and encourage domestic production, raising milk prices for farmers.
• Opponents argue that stricter import controls would increase their costs and result in higher retail food prices, and major foreign suppliers would seek compensation under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules for new restrictions.

<summary>

- The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 (P.L. 110-173) was signed into law on December 29, 2007, and made changes to Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP programs, as well as other federally funded programs.
- The Act suspended the Medicare physician payment cut and provided SCHIP funding through March 2009.
- It also extended various provisions and programs affecting Medicare plans and providers, Medicaid payments and programs, and miscellaneous activities.
- The Act extended the Medicare incentive payment program for certain physicians providing services in scarcity areas and Medicare payments for the accommodation of physicians ordered to active duty in the Armed Services.
- It also extended cost reimbursement for brachytherapy services and cost reimbursement to therapeutic radiopharmaceuticals.
- The Act included provisions that extended the Title V Abstinence Education block grant through June 30, 2008, and amended the Public Health Service Act to provide for research into the prevention of Type I diabetes.
- Grants for the prevention and treatment of diabetes among American Indians and Alaskan Natives were also provided.

</summary>

<summary>

- The "state sponsors of terrorism list" is a designation under the Export Administration Act of 1979, which restricts trade benefits and foreign aid to countries that repeatedly support international terrorism.
- Cuba has been on the list since 1982, along with Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.
- Being on the list restricts bilateral assistance, foreign aid, and trade benefits, and requires validated licenses for exports.
- The President can remove a country from the list by certifying that its government has not supported acts of international terrorism and will not do so in the future.
- Three countries have been removed from the list: South Yemen, Iraq, and Libya.
- Cuba was added to the list in 1982 due to its support for terrorist groups in Latin America, specifically the M-19 guerrilla group in Colombia.
- The United States believes that Cuba has the capacity to develop biological weapons but there is disagreement over whether it has an active program.
- Critics argue that Cuba's presence on the list is a holdover from the Cold War and that it diverts attention from more serious terrorist threats.

</summary>

<summary>

- The U.S. and India established a global partnership in 2005, focusing on economic issues, energy and the environment, democracy and development, non-proliferation and security, and high-technology and space.
- India has maintained positive relations with Iran, including a strategic partnership since 2003, based on historical, civilizational, and multifaceted ties.
- The U.S. has expressed concerns about India's energy commerce with Iran, including the proposed gas pipeline, and defense relations.
- India has voted with the U.S. at the IAEA regarding Iran's nuclear program, but faced criticism from opposition parties and analysts.
- India and Iran have had low-level defense and military relations since the 1980s, with some joint naval exercises and cooperation on weapons upgrades.
- India and Iran are building energy ties, including a proposed gas pipeline and LNG deals, which could conflict with U.S. policy and the Iran Sanctions Act.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) is a program established in 1951 that allows the Departments of Defense and Transportation to work together to manage civil aircraft for military airlift needs during emergencies.
- The program includes three main segments: international, national, and aeromedical evacuation, with commercial airliners providing passenger and cargo pallet transportation.
- The CRAF has been formally activated twice, during Operations Desert Shield/Storm and Operation Iraqi Freedom, and has provided significant cost savings compared to maintaining a larger organic fleet.
</summary>

<summary>

- In October 2000, democratic parties defeated Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic in presidential elections, leading to a transition towards Western democratic and free market standards.
- Serbia has held largely free and fair elections, adopted a new constitution, but faces challenges such as economic crisis, organized crime, and high-level corruption.
- Serbia aims for EU integration but faces opposition due to unresolved issues with its former Kosovo province, which declared independence in 2008.
- The May 6, 2012 elections resulted in a victory for the nationalist Serbian Progressive Party (SNS), a pro-EU coalition, and the Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS).
- In the presidential election, Tomislav Nikolic from the SNS defeated incumbent Boris Tadic.
- The new government, led by Socialist leader Ivica Dacic, faces economic challenges and the need to normalize relations with Kosovo.
- The United States and EU are key players in Serbia's foreign policy, with the EU being the primary focus due to Serbia's EU membership aspirations.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term, including Florida v. Jardines, Florida v. Harris, Bailey v. United States, and Missouri v. McNeely.
- In Florida v. Jardines, the Court held that a dog sniff at the front door of a suspected grow house by a trained narcotics-detection dog is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause.
- In Florida v. Harris, the Court refused to accept a trained drug-detection dog's positive reaction as per se probable cause to search a vehicle. Instead, it listed criteria under which a trained dog's alert might be considered probable cause.
- In Bailey v. United States, the Court held that the detention of an individual who has just left premises to be searched under warrant is permissible when the individual is detained out of view of the house as soon as practicable.
- In Missouri v. McNeely, the Court refused to endorse a per se exception to the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement for nonconsensual blood testing in all drunk-driving cases. Instead, it held that the natural metabolization of alcohol in the bloodstream does not constitute an exigency in every case sufficient to justify conducting a blood test without a warrant.

</summary>

<summary>

• High risk health insurance pools (HRPs) are state-established programs that provide health coverage for individuals with preexisting health conditions who cannot obtain or afford insurance in the private market.
• HRPs were designed to address the insurance needs of individuals who do not have access to employer-sponsored insurance or public programs and undergo rigorous medical underwriting in the individual market.
• HRPs generally operate at a loss and rely on various funding sources, including assessments on insurers, general revenue, and federal grants.
• The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) established a temporary high risk pool program to provide coverage to individuals with preexisting conditions who have been uninsured for six or more months.
• HRPs have existed since the mid-1970s and have received federal support since the 1990s, with various laws and grants authorizing and funding their establishment and operation.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a multilateral organization of 10 Southeast Asian nations with a combined population of 580 million and a GDP of around $1.5 trillion. Established in 1967, ASEAN aims to foster regional dialogue and cooperation on economic growth, regional peace and security, and collaboration in various development areas.
- The Obama Administration has pursued a policy of expanding and upgrading U.S. relations with Southeast Asia and ASEAN, while the Bush Administration was perceived as narrowly focused on terrorism and neglectful of other issues. The United States has deep-seated interests in the region, including maritime security, democracy and human rights, and economic engagement.
- China's growing economic and cultural ties in Southeast Asia and security ties have led to a soft power rivalry with the United States. Other external powers, such as Japan, the EU, and India, have also shown renewed interest in the region.
- The United States has faced a diplomatic dilemma in engaging with ASEAN, despite significant security, economic, and foreign assistance initiatives. Some Southeast Asian elites perceive the United States as insufficiently engaged with the multilateral body and have criticized the lack of high-level diplomatic commitment.
- The Obama Administration has taken steps to address these criticisms, including Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's visits to the ASEAN Secretariat and accession to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. The United States and ASEAN leaders held their first summit in 2009, and the United States has also sought to improve relations with Burma and engage with the Lower Mekong countries.
- ASEAN was founded in 1967 and has since expanded to include 10 members. It operates on principles of consensus and non-interference in the internal affairs of members, and has faced challenges in dealing with underdeveloped nations and diverse interests within the group. The new ASEAN Charter, which came into effect in 2007, commits the member nations to the formation of an "ASEAN Community" and establishes a human rights body.

</summary>

<summary>

• The federal government first supported energy storage and electric power system technology during the 1970s, before the establishment of the Department of Energy (DOE).
• The program focused mainly on energy storage and supporting large coal and nuclear power plants.
• Advancements in computer capacity, miniaturization, and industrial controls expanded the ability of grid operators to monitor and control electric power flows.
• The increase in networking of computerized devices for grid data collection and control advanced the ability of operators to anticipate, avoid, and mitigate potential power crises.
• However, Internet-connected networks have become vulnerable to unwanted computer-driven intrusions and disruptions, revealing a new cybersecurity challenge for electric power systems.
• The energy sector is diverse, including a variety of transmission and distribution system network structures, operating models, and hardware and software.
• Key challenges and opportunities facing the electric power industry include a changing power generation mix, aging infrastructure, modernizing and securing communication networks, accommodating new end-use technologies, planning for increased interdependencies, and devising business models.
• The DOE Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) is charged with supporting more economically competitive, environmentally responsible, secure, and resilient U.S. energy infrastructure.
• OE supports electric grid modernization and resiliency through research and development, demonstration projects, partnerships, modeling and analytics, and emergency preparedness and response.

</summary>

<summary>

- The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency in the U.S. Department of Commerce that advises the Executive Branch on telecommunications and information technology policies, and represents the U.S. in international and domestic telecommunications and information policy activities.
- NTIA oversees the transfer of radio frequencies from the federal domain to the commercial domain, and administers grant programs such as the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program.
- NTIA collaborates with other agencies like the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), the Department of State, the Rural Utilities Service, and the Department of Homeland Security to develop and implement policies related to telecommunications, spectrum management, and public safety communications.
- NTIA supports the Administration's goal of increasing spectrum capacity for mobile broadband by 500 MHz through various means, including evaluating and repurposing spectrum for commercial use, and working with federal agencies to clear spectrum for auction or sharing.

</summary>

<summary>
• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 included provisions to improve electricity reliability and establish federal jurisdiction over electric reliability organizations (EROs).
• The act required FERC to establish an ERO within 180 days, which would develop and enforce reliability standards for the bulk power system, including cybersecurity protection.
• The ERO could impose penalties on violators and FERC could enforce penalties for noncompliance.
• The act also included provisions for siting interstate electric transmission facilities, including a study of electric transmission congestion every three years and the potential for federal authorization to issue construction permits.
• The act established incentive-based transmission rates to promote reliable and economically efficient electric transmission and generation, and allowed for the recovery of all prudently incurred costs necessary to comply with mandatory reliability standards.
</summary>

* Adults may go missing for various reasons, including personal choice, disabling conditions, natural disasters, or crime.
* The proposed Silver Alert communications network aims to assist in recovering missing seniors by establishing voluntary guidelines, protocols, and a national coordinator.
* State alert systems for missing adults vary in legal authority, target population, administrative responsibility, training, process for activating alerts, interstate coordination, system costs, use of the system, and outcomes.

<summary>

- The District of Columbia has been the site of over 100 memorials since the approval of a statue for George Washington in 1783.
- Prior to 1986, there were no statutory criteria for authorizing commemorative works, and site locations and memorial designs were approved by Congress.
- In 1986, the Commemorative Works Act was passed to guide the memorial creation process in the District of Columbia.
- The Act aims to preserve the integrity of the L'Enfant and McMillan plans for the Nation's Capital, ensure public use and enjoyment of open space, and encourage the location of commemorative works within the urban fabric.
- The Act defines a commemorative work as any statue, monument, sculpture, memorial, plaque, inscription, or other structure or landscape feature designed to perpetuate the memory of an individual, group, event, or other significant element of American history.
- The Act does not apply to military properties or lands under the jurisdiction of the Smithsonian or the Architect of the Capitol.
- The process for creating a memorial in the District of Columbia involves 24 steps, including seeking National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission assistance, drafting and introducing a bill, site selection, design approval, fundraising, and construction.
- The National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission, U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, National Capital Planning Commission, District of Columbia Historic Preservation Office, and American Battle Monuments Commission are entities responsible for memorials in the District of Columbia.
- The Commemorative Works Act has been amended several times since its enactment to address issues such as donor recognition and legislative authority extensions.

</summary>

<summary>

- The America's Healthy Future Act of 2009, S. 1796, was approved by the Senate Finance Committee on October 19, 2009, and includes provisions affecting private health insurance in Titles I and VI.
- Title I focuses on restructuring the private health insurance market, setting minimum standards for health benefits, and providing financial assistance to individuals and small employers.
- Individuals are required to maintain health insurance, and certain employers with more than 50 employees must either provide insurance or pay a tax.
- Market reforms include modified community rating, guaranteed issue, and insurance renewal, all linked to essential health benefits coverage.
- Qualifying coverage includes QHBPs, new group or individual coverage, grandfathered employment-based plans, grandfathered nongroup plans, and other coverage like Medicare and Medicaid.
- Title VI includes revenue provisions to pay for expanded health insurance coverage, including excise taxes and annual fees on health insurers, as well as limitations on executive compensation and tax-advantaged accounts.
- The bill establishes exchanges where individuals and small businesses can access private plans in a comparable way, and certain individuals with incomes below 400% of the federal poverty level can qualify for premium credits and cost-sharing subsidies.
- States have the flexibility to establish basic plans for low-income individuals not eligible for Medicaid.
- The Congressional Budget Office projects that the legislation would reduce federal deficits by $81 billion over a 10-year period and insure 94% of the non-elderly, legally present U.S. population by 2019.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Robinson-Patman Act was enacted in 1936 to allow small businesses to compete effectively with larger rivals in the purchase of commodities.
• The act prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality."
• The Nonprofit Institutions Act of 1938 created a broad exemption from the Robinson-Patman Act for purchases made by nonprofit organizations for their own use.
• The Supreme Court has interpreted the nonprofit exemption narrowly, limiting it to purchases made for the specific needs of the organization and its staff.
• The Robinson-Patman Act does not explicitly list health maintenance organizations (HMOs) as charitable institutions, but some courts have ruled that they qualify for the nonprofit exemption.
• The successful plaintiff in a Robinson-Patman Act lawsuit is not automatically entitled to damages equal to the unlawful price differential.

</summary>

* The document provides an analysis of annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2017, comparing enacted FY2016 appropriations, Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, Trump Administration's requests for additional funding, and appropriations measures developed in response.
* The report identifies additional resources and experts for further context on DHS appropriations, and explains budgetary concepts such as budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, offsetting collections, allocations, and adjustments to the discretionary spending caps under the Budget Control Act.

<summary>

• In 2013, the official U.S. poverty rate was 14.5%, a statistically significant drop from 15.0% in 2012.
• 45.3 million persons were estimated as having income below the official poverty line, a number statistically unchanged from 2012.
• The poverty rate tends to follow the economic cycle, rising during economic recessions and falling during economic growth.
• The poverty rate for non-aged adults reached a record high of 13.8% in 2010 and remained statistically unchanged in 2013.
• The poverty rate for children fell from 21.3% in 2012 to 19.5% in 2013, but still exceeded the pre-recession low of 16.9%.
• The poverty rate among foreign-born persons dropped significantly in 2013, but poverty among children remained high.
• The Census Bureau has developed a new Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) to address criticisms of the official poverty measure, which will be discussed in a separate section.

</summary>

• The United States and New Zealand have rekindled their high-level security partnership, with New Zealand's nuclear policies no longer defining their relationship. They are once again close security partners in the Asia Pacific and beyond.
• The Wellington Declaration of 2010 marked a turning point in United States-New Zealand relations, enabling a reorientation of the bilateral relationship and opening the way for further enhanced strategic dialogue and defense cooperation.

<summary>

- Trade plays a significant role in the U.S. agricultural sector, with exports accounting for approximately 20% of total agricultural production.
- U.S. farm policy is subject to intense scrutiny for compliance with WTO rules and potential impact on multilateral negotiations due to the farm bill's long-term implications.
- The Agricultural Act of 2014 made substantial changes to previous farm safety net programs and became operational for the 2014 crop year.
- The WTO's Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) and Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM) are the most relevant commitments for U.S. domestic farm policy.
- The AoA categorizes agricultural domestic support programs based on their potential to distort markets and sets country-specific spending limits on the most market-distorting policies.
- The SCM evaluates the market distortion of a program or policy in terms of its measurable market effects on international trade and/or market price for the affected commodity.
- Green Box programs are minimally or non-trade distorting and not subject to any spending limits, while Blue Box programs are production-limiting and not subject to payment limits.
- Amber Box programs are the most market-distorting and subject to strict aggregate, annual spending limits. The United States is subject to a spending limit of $19.1 billion in amber box outlays.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Take Care Clause of the U.S. Constitution requires the President to "take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed."
• The clause has been interpreted as placing an obligation on the President and those under his supervision to comply with and execute clear statutory directives as enacted by Congress.
• The Supreme Court has also construed the Clause as ensuring Presidential control over the enforcement of federal law.
• Courts generally will not review Presidential enforcement decisions, including the decision of whether to initiate a criminal prosecution or administrative enforcement action in response to a violation of federal law or regulation.
• The President plays a significant role in the legislative process, but once a bill is enacted into law, the President's legislative role comes to an end and is supplanted by his express constitutional obligation under Article II, §3 to "take Care that the Law[] be faithfully executed."
• The Marbury v. Madison case established that when an executive officer fails to perform a "specific duty [] assigned by law," the courts may enforce the obligation through a writ of mandamus.
• The Kendall v. United States ex rel. Stokes case held that the President has no authority to direct the performance of a statutory obligation by an executive branch official, and any interpretation of the Constitution that characterized the obligation of an executive branch official to execute the law as arising from the direction of the President alone is inadmissible.
• The Supreme Court's decision in Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer invalidated President Harry Truman's directive to seize steel mills during a labor dispute, holding that the Constitution limits the President's functions in the lawmaking process to recommending laws he supports, vetoing laws he opposes, and executing laws that have been enacted by Congress.
• Congress may restrict executive discretion in the enforcement of federal law through statute, but the precise limits of this authority have not been clearly defined by the Supreme Court.

</summary>

<summary>
• The Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 (Perkins IV) reauthorizes and amends the Perkins Act, which provides funding for career and technical education.
• Perkins IV retains the overall purpose and structure of the Perkins Act, but makes changes to funding formulas, accountability requirements, state and local plans, and the tech-prep program.
• Changes to funding formulas include a reduction in the percentage reserved for assistance for outlying areas and an increase in direct grants to these areas. The percentage reserved for incentive grants has been repealed.
• Accountability requirements include separate core indicators of performance for the secondary and postsecondary levels, which are linked to ESEA. Eligible agencies and recipients must meet at least 90% of an adjusted level of performance for each core indicator or develop an improvement plan.
• The tech-prep program is expanded to include a link to ESEA and requires consortia receiving funding to establish and report on indicators of performance related to tech-prep participants. If a consortium fails to meet performance levels for three consecutive years, the eligible agency may require the consortium to resubmit an application for a tech-prep grant or terminate funding.
</summary>

<summary>

• The campus-based programs, including the Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG), Federal Work-Study (FWS), and Federal Perkins Loan programs, were authorized under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and are collectively referred to as the "campus-based" programs.

• These programs are unique because federal funds are awarded directly to institutions, which determine the mix and amount of aid awarded to students based on institution-specific award criteria.

• The FSEOG and FWS programs have continued to be funded through annual appropriation bills, while the Perkins Loan program was amended and extended through FY2017.

• The campus-based programs have come to play a smaller role in the federal student aid effort as most forms of aid are now portable.

• The Perkins Loan program was originally enacted in 1958 as a response to the space race and concerns over national security, and was designed to provide low-interest rate loans to students with financial need.

• Institutions were required to give special consideration to students in certain majors and those intending to teach when selecting award recipients.

• The Perkins Loan program was later incorporated into the HEA and funding for it was allocated to institutions through a two-stage state distribution formula.

• The Perkins Loan program has been subject to several revisions over the years, including changes to the institutional match, loan cancellation and deferment provisions, and student eligibility.

• Issues related to the campus-based programs that may be considered during HEA reauthorization include the extent to which they provide types of aid not provided via other postsecondary aid programs, the optimal formula for allocating funds to institutions, and the potential role of the campus-based aid programs in a redesigned federal aid system.

</summary>

<summary>

• The September 11, 2001, attacks brought attention to the vulnerability of water supply and quality infrastructure to terrorist attacks.
• Water infrastructure systems include surface and ground water sources, dams, reservoirs, treatment facilities, finished water reservoirs, distribution systems, and wastewater collection and treatment facilities.
• The federal government owns a small percentage of the dams whose failure could result in loss of life or significant property damage, while the remaining dams belong to state or local governments, utilities, and corporate or private owners.
• Large drinking water and wastewater utilities located primarily in urban areas serve more than 75% of the U.S. population and represent the greatest targets for terrorist attacks.
• Bioterrorism or chemical attacks could deliver widespread contamination with small amounts of microbiological agents or toxic chemicals, endangering public health and the environment.
• Cyber attacks on computer operations can affect an entire infrastructure network, and hacking in water utility systems could result in theft or corruption of information or denial and disruption of service.
• Since the 2001 terrorist attacks, many water and wastewater utilities have switched from using chlorine gas as disinfection to alternatives believed to be safer, such as sodium hypochlorite or ultraviolet light.
• There are no federal standards or agreed-upon practices within the water infrastructure sector to govern readiness, response to security incidents, and recovery.
• EPA has taken organizational and planning steps to strengthen water security, including the creation of a National Homeland Security Research Center and a Water Security Division.

</summary>

* The Federal immigration laws establish procedures for excluding and removing non-U.S. nationals who do not meet specified criteria regarding their entry or presence within the United States.
* Aliens within the United States may not be removed without due process, but Congress has broad authority over the admission of aliens seeking to enter the country.
* The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 established the expedited removal process for arriving aliens who lack valid entry documents or have attempted to gain admission through fraud or misrepresentation.
* The expedited removal process allows for the summary removal of these aliens without a hearing or further review, but in limited circumstances, they may be entitled to certain procedural protections before removal.

<summary>

- The federal estate and gift taxes are unified taxes with the same rate structure and a shared lifetime transfer credit. The unified credit covers an applicable amount of $5,340,000 per individual in 2014.
- The gross estate of a decedent includes all property owned by the decedent on the date of death, as well as certain transfers made prior to death. Proceeds from life insurance policies and survivor annuities may also be included.
- The taxable estate is determined by reducing the gross estate with allowable deductions, including estate administration expenses, debts, charitable bequests, and state death taxes. The marital deduction allows for the value of all property passing to a surviving spouse to be excluded from the taxable estate.
- The federal gift tax is a tax on gratuitous transfers made during life and seeks to account for reductions in estate and accordingly estate tax liability at death. The donor's tax liability depends on the value of the taxable gift, which is determined by reducing the gross value with available deductions and exclusions.
- The generation-skipping transfer tax is a flat-rate tax applied to transfers to a person two or more generations below the transferor. The tax rate is set at the highest estate tax rate (currently 40%) and is applied to direct skips, taxable terminations, and taxable distributions.

</summary>

<summary>

- Cabo Verde is a small island nation with historical ties to the United States and is considered an important U.S. partner in West Africa.
- Its strategic location makes it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine bound for Europe and a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic.
- U.S.-Cabo Verdean cooperation focuses on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects.
- Cabo Verde is eligible for tariff preferences under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), although its use of these benefits is minimal.
- Cabo Verde became a democracy in 1991 after increasing demands for a multi-party political system and has since held multi-party elections.
- The MPD, a democratic party, has dominated politics since the transition to democracy and has pursued economic reforms and diversified trade relations.
- Cabo Verde faces challenges such as water shortages, poverty, and rule of law issues, but has made progress in areas such as health, education, and poverty reduction.
- The country has received significant development assistance from the MCC and has been pursuing deeper bilateral and investment ties with countries such as China, Brazil, and Angola.
- Narcotics trafficking poses a significant threat in Cabo Verde and the United States provides assistance to help Cabo Verdean authorities investigate and prosecute drug cases and counter drug trafficking.

</summary>

<summary>

- Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a critical function in protecting Americans from terrorists and their weapons.
- The development of border security policies can be seen as a series of concentric circles or screens, starting with prevention abroad and progressing through other stages as needed.
- Congressional concern with terrorism and border security began in the 1990s following a series of terrorist attacks, culminating in the 9/11 attacks.
- In response, Congress created several commissions to understand the nature of the terrorist threat and structural changes to provide a framework for action.
- Specific actions were taken to protect against immediate threats, such as the implementation of entry and exit control systems, biometric identifiers in travel documents, and intelligence sharing among federal law enforcement and immigration agencies.
- More recent efforts have focused on broader, more comprehensive approaches to border and transportation security, including the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004.
- Current border security activities include the functions of the Department of Homeland Security's Directorate of Border and Transportation Security, including Customs and Border Protection, the Coast Guard, and the Transportation Security Administration.
- Technologies such as biometric identifiers, smart containers, and unmanned aerial vehicles are being used to enhance border security.
- Ongoing efforts include the expansion of pre-inspection sites at foreign airports, the development of a smart container program, and the use of technology to enhance border surveillance.

</summary>

<summary>

- Severe fire seasons have led to increased debate and proposals related to fire protection programs and funding since 2000.
- President Clinton proposed a National Fire Plan in 2000 to increase funding for federal, state, and private lands protection.
- The Healthy Forests Initiative was proposed by President Bush in 2002 to expedite fuel reduction on federal lands.
- The FLAME Act was enacted in 2009 to insulate other agency programs from high wildfire suppression costs.
- Wildfire funding has remained high since 2000, with federal land management agency budgets showing substantial increases.
- Concerns persist about the high costs of wildfire management and the indirect effects on other agency programs.
- Reports recommend increasing local responsibility for wildfire protection and suppression for non-federal lands and structures, and better cost control and accountability.

</summary>

- During New York debates ratifying the U.S. Constitution, Hamilton emphasized the principle of "the people should choose whom they please to govern them."
- Prior to the 1960s, court challenges to redistricting plans were considered non-justiciable political questions.
- In 1962, the Supreme Court shifted its stance in Baker v. Carr, holding that a constitutional challenge to a redistricting plan was justiciable.
- Since then, various constitutional and legal challenges have shaped congressional redistricting.
- The Supreme Court recently clarified how a court should evaluate race as a factor in redistricting plans when considering a Fourteenth Amendment equal protection claim.
- The Court also upheld an Arizona constitutional provision that established an independent commission for drawing congressional districts.
- During the 2015 term, the Court ruled that states may draw legislative districts based on total population rather than eligible or registered voters.
- Two redistricting cases are currently pending before the Court, one addressing partisanship in state legislative redistricting and another concerning the burden of proof in racial gerrymandering claims.
- Key constitutional and federal statutory requirements for congressional redistricting include the standard for equality of population among districts and the Voting Rights Act (VRA).

</summary>

<summary>

• The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods for Presidential appointments: with Senate consent or during Senate recesses.
• President Obama had difficulty obtaining Senate confirmation for nominations to the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (CFPB) and the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB).
• President Obama nominated Richard Cordray to be the first Director of the CFPB in July 2011, but faced opposition from Senators who wanted structural changes to the Bureau.
• The Senate Banking Committee approved Cordray's nomination, but the Senate fell short of the 60 votes needed to reach cloture and move to a vote.
• The NLRB, an agency with the power to investigate and adjudicate unfair labor practices, had vacancies during the presidencies of both George W. Bush and Obama.
• In 2010, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the NLRB could not exercise rulemaking powers without three or more acting members.
• In an effort to prevent board membership from dropping below the minimum quorum required for the NLRB to fully conduct business, President Obama nominated Terrence F. Flynn, Sharon Block, and Richard F. Griffin Jr. to be Board members.
• However, the Senate did not confirm any of the nominees before the third member's term expired.
• Following Senate inaction, President Obama considered making recess appointments during Senate pro forma sessions.
• The political question doctrine, which asks whether a claim is inappropriate for judicial review, may impede a reviewing court from reaching the merits of a potential legal challenge to the appointments.

</summary>

<summary>

- TAA is a federal program that provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition or offshoring.
- Benefits include funding for training and reemployment services, income support, and a tax credit for health insurance premiums.
- TAA was reauthorized by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA) and is currently authorized through June 30, 2021.
- TAA is jointly administered by the federal government and states, with funding from mandatory appropriations.
- Eligibility criteria include job loss due to increased imports, production shifts to foreign countries, and adverse effects on secondary workers.
- TAA is subject to sequestration under the Budget Control Act of 2011 and was reduced by 6.6% in FY2018.

</summary>

<summary>

- About 27.5% of state and local government employees (approximately 6.6 million persons) work in positions not covered by Social Security.
- Coverage rates vary across states, with some states having over 95% coverage and others under 5%.
- Congress made Social Security coverage mandatory for most state and local government employees not already covered by public pension plans in 1991.
- Public employees with pension plans but not covered by Social Security may hold a referendum to elect coverage.
- Once coverage is provided, it generally cannot be terminated, and future employees in covered positions are required to participate.
- Proposals have been made to mandate Social Security coverage for all newly hired state and local government employees to increase universality.
- Mandatory coverage is projected to have a net positive effect on the Social Security Trust Funds, closing a portion of the projected long-range funding shortfall.
- Opponents argue that mandatory coverage could result in reduced pension benefits or higher payroll taxes and lower benefits for current workers.

</summary>

• To be eligible for funding, each state must prepare a State Forest Action Plan and have a State Forest Stewardship Coordination Committee.
• Funding for forestry assistance programs has declined over the past 15 years, with an average annual appropriation of $362.7 million and a peak of $420.5 million in FY2010. Some programs have been repealed or unfunded, but others continue through other authorizations or funding sources.

* The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) requires federally inspected packers to report prices and other information on livestock and meat purchases to the USDA. The act was reauthorized until September 30, 2020, in the Agriculture Reauthorizations Act of 2015.
* LMR reporting requirements include daily and weekly reports on prices, quantities, and quality characteristics for cattle, swine, sows and boars, lambs, and boxed beef, wholesale pork, and carcass and boxed lamb. Confidentiality rules protect the identity of packers and contracts and proprietary business information. AMS compiles and disseminates the information collected under LMR through daily and weekly reports. AMS enforces LMR through audits and fines for non-compliance.

• The Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP) was established in 2006 under the Federal Employee Dental and Vision Benefits Enhancement Act of 2004.
• FEDVIP offers supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and their dependents. Enrollees are responsible for 100% of the premiums.
• There are four nationwide dental plans and three regional dental plans, as well as three vision plans, all providing both nationwide and overseas coverage.
• Eligible individuals can enroll during the standard open season for FEHB plans or following a qualifying life event. Premiums vary by plan, location, and family size.
• FEDVIP plans pay secondary to primary coverage under an individual's FEHB plan, and active employees can pay premiums on a pre-tax basis.

• In 2008, an unknown programmer or group of programmers using the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto created Bitcoin, the first cryptocurrency, which allows users to make digital transfers of value through a decentralized network.
• Cryptocurrencies have grown from little-known technologies to financially significant instruments, with uses including fundraising through initial coin offerings and derivatives based on their value.
• Money exists to facilitate the exchange of goods and services, and cryptocurrencies aim to function as alternative electronic payment systems.
• Cryptocurrencies have advantages over traditional payment systems, such as potentially lower costs for international transactions and increased privacy for users.
• However, cryptocurrencies face challenges, including their volatility, limited scalability, and potential use in criminal activities.
• Policymakers must consider the implications of cryptocurrencies, including their potential role in monetary policy, consumer protection, and criminal activity.

- The Administration's request focuses on "early-stage R&D," while both the House and Senate bills provide funding for later-stage R&D and deployment projects.
- The House and Senate bills both reject the Administration's proposal to eliminate the Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program.

- Transnational organized crime groups, including those involved in drug trafficking, human trafficking, gun trafficking, wildlife trafficking, and gem and timber trafficking, flourish in Burma, generating several billion dollars each year.
- Corruption among officials in Burma's ruling military junta, the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC), facilitates trafficking and provides criminal underground immunity from law enforcement and judicial action.
- The country's large extra-legal economy, both black market and illicit border trade, makes it difficult to assess the size and structure of Burma's economy.
- The U.S. government has imposed sanctions on Burma due to its status as a major drug-producing state and its non-compliance with minimum standards for the elimination of trafficking in persons.
- Burma is a major producer of illicit opium, heroin, and methamphetamine, and is the world's second-largest producer of illicit opium after Afghanistan.
- The influence of organized crime in Burma and the region could remain virtually impossible to reduce due to widespread collusion with junta military, police, and political officials.

</summary>

<summary>

- A sitting United States Senator who is indicted for a felony does not automatically lose their status or service in Congress.
- Internal party rules, such as the Senate Republican Conference Rules, may require an indicted chairman or ranking Member of a Senate committee, or a member of Senate party leadership, to temporarily step aside from their leadership or chairmanship position.
- Members of Congress do not automatically forfeit their offices upon conviction of a felony, but they may lose their chairmanships or ranking Member status on committees.
- Conviction of certain crimes may subject Senators to internal legislative disciplinary proceedings, including resolutions of censure or expulsion from the Senate.
- Expulsion from Congress does not result in the forfeiture or loss of one's federal pension, but conviction of certain crimes may lead to the forfeiture of retirement annuities or the loss of all creditable service towards a federal pension.
- Indictment and/or conviction of a felony does not disqualify one from being a Member of Congress, unless the conviction is for treasonous conduct committed after taking an oath of office.
- The United States Constitution does not provide for the recall of any United States officials, including Members of Congress, and no Member has ever been recalled in the history of the United States.

</summary>

<summary>

• The presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and the scientific workforce has been a concern in the scientific community.
• Enrollment of U.S. citizens in graduate science and engineering programs has not kept pace with that of foreign students.
• Approximately 56% of foreign doctorate degree earners on temporary visas remain in the United States and many eventually become citizens.
• In 2008, approximately 15.0% of those individuals awarded legal permanent resident status resulted from employment-based preferences.
• U.S. universities and industry have chosen foreign talent to fill many positions, particularly at the doctorate level and in major roles at the masters level.
• Critics argue that U.S. workers are adversely affected by the entry of foreign scientists and engineers, who reportedly accept lower wages.
• The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that employment in science and engineering fields will increase at a faster rate than other professional groups between 2006 and 2016.
• The H-1B temporary admissions program has been a subject of debate due to concerns over job opportunities, salaries, and working conditions for U.S. scientific personnel.
• The number of foreign-born students in U.S. colleges and universities increased by 8.0% in 2008-2009, with significant growth from China and India.
• The scientific community is divided over proposals to impose stricter immigration limits on people with scientific and technical skills, with debates continuing on the balance between a highly skilled workforce and job opportunities for U.S. scientific personnel.

</summary>

* The Affordable Care Act (ACA) has led to significant federal mandatory spending, primarily for expanding health insurance coverage.
* Spending on premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions totaled $79.2 billion in the first three fiscal years.
* For calendar year 2014, states that implemented Medicaid expansion reported spending $36.7 billion on newly eligible adults, fully funded by federal funds.
* The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projects gross spending on insurance coverage expansion under the ACA will total $1.938 trillion over 10 years.
* The ACA includes numerous appropriations and transfers of funds from the Medicare Part A and Part B trust funds to support various programs and activities.
* The ACA funded temporary health care programs for targeted groups prior to the health insurance exchanges becoming operational, including the Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan, a temporary reinsurance program, and the Consumer Operated and Oriented Plan program.
* The ACA established the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation and the Independent Payment Advisory Board, and appropriated substantial amounts to each.
* The Community Health Center Fund and the Prevention and Public Health Fund are two special funds established by the ACA, with significant annual appropriations.
* The ACA appropriations are subject to sequestration, except for insurance expansion coverage, but only new budget authority for nondefense programs is sequestrable in any given fiscal year.
* The ACA provided over $100 billion in mandatory appropriations and Medicare fund transfers over the 10-year period FY2010-FY2019, with only four provisions being permanent.

</summary>

• The Millennium Challenge Account (MCA) is a new initiative aimed at increasing foreign economic assistance to low and lower-middle income countries based on their past performance.
• The MCA legislation, signed into law in 2004, created a new entity called the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) to manage the initiative, and allocated $994 million for FY2004. The legislation also established a process for selecting countries based on their performance in three areas: ruling justly, investing in people, and pursuing sound economic policies.

- The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA) provided $17.15 billion in supplemental discretionary appropriations for biomedical research, public health, and other health-related programs within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
- ARRA included new authorizing language to promote the widespread adoption of electronic health records and other health information technology (HIT), and established a federal interagency advisory panel to coordinate comparative effectiveness research.
- ARRA funds were designated as emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2009 and were to remain available for obligation through the end of FY2010. Most health-related programs and activities also receive funding through regular appropriations.
- The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) issued detailed government-wide guidance for implementing ARRA and established a website, "Recovery.gov," to track ARRA spending.
- ARRA provided $2 billion to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) for grants to health centers and health workforce programs.
- HRSA allocated $1.5 billion for health center infrastructure, including construction and renovation of health centers and acquisition of HIT systems, and $500 million for operating grants to health centers.
- ARRA provided $1.1 billion to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) for comparative effectiveness research (CER), and instructed the Secretary to contract with the Institute of Medicine (IOM) to produce a report on national CER priorities.
- ARRA established an interagency advisory panel, the Federal Coordinating Council for Comparative Effectiveness Research, to help coordinate and support CER, and included language stating that the council may not mandate coverage, reimbursement, or other policies for public and private payers of health care.

</summary>

<summary>

• Total private nonfarm employment fell from 111.6 million in February 2001 to 108.4 million in July 2003, then expanded through 2007.
• Net job loss is the result of greater gross job loss than gross job gains, while gross job loss is a normal part of a functioning market economy.
• In expansions, labor market is characterized by net job creation amidst gross job loss to maintain steady employment rates.
• During recessions, overall labor market experiences persistent net job loss.
• Small businesses account for a disproportionate share of both gross job gains and losses, but net job gains are less than gross flows would indicate.
• Trade liberalization has no effect on net employment historically, as shown in Figure 3.
• Policymakers can use expansionary monetary or fiscal policy to stimulate aggregate spending and offset net job loss.

</summary>

The text does not take a position on the veracity of claims of substandard medical care or ICE's rebuttals.

• Abe secured a three-year term as party president in 2018, ensuring his continuation as prime minister.

- The report discusses appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2016, focusing on the components labeled as "Departmental Management and Operations."
- The Administration requested $1,396 million for these accounts, an increase of $255 million from FY2015. The Senate-reported bill provided $1,346 million, a decrease of $73 million from the request. The House-reported bill provided $1,217 million, a decrease of $178 million from the request.

<summary>

- Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code allows financially troubled business debtors to reorganize their financial affairs and remain in business.
- In a business reorganization under chapter 11, the debtor generally remains in possession and no trustee is appointed.
- The Bankruptcy Code provides debtors the opportunity to assume or reject executory contracts, including collective bargaining agreements (CBAs), but the process for rejecting CBAs is more complex.
- Section 1113 of the Bankruptcy Code outlines the requirements for rejecting a CBA and applies only to chapter 11 bankruptcies.
- The section was added in response to the U.S. Supreme Court's holding in National Labor Relations Board v. Bildisco and Bildisco, which established a standard for CBA rejection.
- H.R. 3652, also known as the "Protecting Employees and Retirees in Business Bankruptcies Act of 2007," proposes modifications to section 1113.
- The bill asserts that workers and retirees are being disproportionately burdened in business bankruptcies and urges comprehensive reform to address these inequities.
- The bill would limit the modifications that debtors can propose to CBAs and require court approval only if the proposals meet certain requirements.
- The bill would also extend the time required for notice before a hearing on a motion to reject a CBA and limit the parties who can appear and be heard.
- The bill would define rejection of a CBA as a breach and address the effect of rejection in terms of both money damages and the right of affected employees to strike.

</summary>

* The study compared the effects of gelc-ms/ms with repetitive injections and additional protein prefractionation using microsol ief on depth of analysis and reproducibility using cancer cell lysates.
* The results showed that microsol ief fractionation prior to gelc-ms/ms significantly improved proteome coverage and reproducibility compared to repetitive injections using equal amounts of mass spectrometer time.

* The text discusses the use of counter-cyclical assistance in U.S. farming, including historical forms such as deficiency payments and marketing assistance loans, and the new counter-cyclical measures introduced in the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002.
* Counter-cyclical assistance is intended to help farmers during periods of low commodity prices by providing payments based on historical production or target prices, and is designed to be decoupled from current output to avoid violating world trade commitments. However, the administrative, economic, and political implications of changing or reducing benefits are a concern.

• The study compared the incidence of secondary, delayed postoperative hemorrhage between tonsillectomy and submucosal uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (smuppp) procedures at their institution.
• The study found that the incidence of secondary, delayed hemorrhage was significantly lower in the smuppp group (1.45%) compared to the tonsillectomy group (5.05%).

<summary>

• Congress has used commemoratives to express gratitude, dramatize virtues, and perpetuate remembrance since its inception
• Commemoratives have evolved from individually struck medals to legislation for federal holidays and building names
• Types of commemoratives include legislative and nonlegislative options
• Legislative options require passage of a bill or resolution, such as naming federal buildings or creating monuments
• Nonlegislative options include sending certificates of recognition and giving floor speeches
• House Rule XII, clause 5 prohibits the introduction or consideration of commemorative legislation that includes a specified period of time
• Commemorative commissions are entities established to oversee commemorations of people or events, often funded through appropriations or nonfederal money
• Federal holidays are established through legislation and include 11 permanent holidays, such as New Year's Day and Memorial Day

</summary>

<summary>

• The United States and Vietnam established diplomatic relations in 1995 and have since expanded cooperation in various sectors, including nuclear energy.
• A civilian nuclear cooperation agreement was signed between the two countries in May 2014 under Section 123 of the Atomic Energy Act.
• The agreement was subject to congressional review and entered into force after the review period was completed on September 9, 2014.
• During the review period, issues such as nonproliferation commitments, human rights record, strategic relationship, and U.S. industry benefits were prominent.
• Vietnam has nuclear cooperation agreements with several other countries, including Russia, France, China, South Korea, Japan, and Canada.
• The U.S. nuclear industry may benefit from the agreement, with potential exports estimated to be billions of dollars.
• The first major step towards the agreement was a 2008 agreement to strengthen nuclear safety and regulatory frameworks in Vietnam.

</summary>

<summary>

- Inland waterways carry approximately one-sixth of the national volume of intercity cargo and handle approximately half of all inland waterway freight.
- The Corps manages and maintains the infrastructure of these commercial waterways, including navigation channels, harbors, locks, and dams.
- Costs for maintenance and construction on inland waterways are funded by the Corps and the commercial user industry through user fees.
- The Corps pays for 100% of the cost for studies and for operations and maintenance on the IWS, while the cost for new construction or major rehabilitation is shared equally between the Corps and the commercial industry.
- The current revenue source, a set tax on fuel, is insufficient to cover nonfederal costs of major capital expenditures, resulting in federal taxpayers covering more than half of these costs.
- Recent proposals include increasing the fuel tax and increasing the federal share for inland waterway costs.
- The IWUB, a federal advisory committee, was established to give commercial users an opportunity to inform federal decision-making on IWTF projects.
- The IWTF balance has varied considerably since 1986, with significant increases and sharp declines due to increased expenditures and cost overruns.
- The IWTF financing system and the equity of the financing system for fuel-taxed inland waterways have raised concerns, leading to recent proposals to address these issues.

</summary>

<summary>

- In 2005, North Korea announced it had nuclear weapons and suspended participation in the Six-Party Talks, leading to little progress in resolving the nuclear issue. Key events included North Korea's removal of fuel rods from the Yongbyon reactor for reprocessing and the launch of a short-range missile.
- The fourth round of Six-Party Talks in Beijing resulted in a joint statement committing North Korea to abandoning all nuclear weapons and returning to the NPT and IAEA safeguards. However, disagreements over North Korea's right to develop peaceful nuclear energy programs and the imposition of sanctions on a Macau bank for alleged North Korean counterfeit dollar transactions stalled the talks.
- The year also saw increased attention to North Korea's human rights record and criminal activities. The United States imposed penalties on a Macau bank for alleged North Korean counterfeit dollar laundering, and North Korea rejected aid from the European Union and suspended food aid from the World Food Program.

</summary>

- The text describes the development of a post-coupling methodology for attaching biological targeting ligands to nanoparticles with controlled mol% attachment and ligand orientation.
- The methodology was inspired by the chemistry used to create ph-triggered, pegylated sirna nanoparticles and involved the synthesis of hybrid targeting ligands with a peptide targeting moiety conjugated to a peg extension chain.

</summary>

<summary>

- The America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010 (COMPETES 2010) authorized approximately $45.5 billion in funding between FY2010 and FY2013 for federal research in the physical sciences and engineering, STEM education, and other related programs.
- COMPETES 2010 increased funding authorizations for the National Science Foundation (NSF), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), and Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Science, and established new programs like inducement prizes, a loan guarantee program, and the Regional Innovation Program (RIP).
- The President's FY2013 budget request sought increased funding for the doubling path accounts but did not include funding for many COMPETES 2010-authorized STEM education programs.
- The Administration's FY2013 budget request specifically included funding for the Regional Innovation Program (RIP) at the Department of Commerce (DOC) but did not seek funding for the NIST Green Jobs Act, Federal Loan Guarantees for Innovative Technologies in Manufacturing, or the STEM-Training Grant program.
- FY2013 post-rescission, post-sequestration funding for NSF was $6.884 billion, which was $1.416 billion (17.1%) less than the COMPETES 2010 authorized funding level of $8.300 billion.
- FY2013 post-rescission, post-sequestration funding for NIST was $769.4 million, which was $270.3 million (26.0%) less than the COMPETES 2010 authorized funding level of $1.040 billion.
- The COMPETES acts were designed to improve U.S. competitiveness by fostering scientific and technological innovation through increases in authorized funding for physical sciences and engineering research and STEM education program authorizations.

</summary>

<summary>

- The study evaluated the effect of a sublingual nitroglycerin spray formulation on exercise tolerance in patients with chronic stable angina.
- The study was carried out at four centers in the US and followed international conference on harmonisation and FDA guidelines.
- Patients were adults with coronary artery disease, chronic stable exertional angina, and a stable medical treatment regimen for their angina for at least 2 months prior to study entry.
- Patients who developed angina within 39 minutes of commencing exercise and were able to exercise for 60 seconds longer in the subsequent test were eligible to continue in the study.
- The study used a crossover design with each patient serving as their own control to minimize the impact of any training effect.
- Primary efficacy endpoints were time to onset of angina symptoms and time to development of moderate angina, while the secondary endpoint was time to 1-mm st-segment depression.
- The study showed a dose-dependent increase in time to onset of moderate angina, with the most pronounced effect in the 1.6-mg group.
- The study demonstrated that sublingual nitroglycerin spray was generally well tolerated, but the incidence of headache was dose dependent.

</summary>

<summary>

• Transplantation of kidneys in Fischer-344 (F344) to Lewis rat strain combination is used to study chronic allograft injury (CAI).
• Acute rejection of F344 to Lewis renal allografts is characterized by strong mononuclear infiltration and elevated intravascular leukocytes, predominantly monocytes.
• Mononuclear leukocytes isolated from allografts on day 9 and day 42 after transplantation show increased tgm2 mRNA and protein expression compared to isografts.
• Active caspase-3, a key protease in apoptosis, is expressed by intravascular graft leukocytes during reversible acute rejection.
• Cystamine treatment did not prevent intimal hyperplasia or arterial remodeling in the sham-treated group, and no significant difference in arterial thickness was observed between placebo- and cystamine-treated groups.
• Tgm2 is overexpressed by mononuclear leukocytes, predominantly activated monocytes, in the vascular bed of rat renal allografts during acute rejection.
• The role of tgm2 in the pathogenesis of CAI is still unclear, and further studies are needed to determine if it is a marker of CAI or actively contributes to its development.

</summary>

<summary>

- The Lacey Act was enacted in 1900 to address wildlife poaching and wildlife laundering, and was amended in 2008 to include nonindigenous plants and violations of foreign laws related to conservation actions and other activities involving plants and plant products.
- The Lacey Act now makes it unlawful for any person to import, export, transport, sell, receive, acquire, or purchase in interstate or foreign commerce any plant taken, possessed, transported, or sold in violation of any law or regulation of any state or foreign law that protects plants or regulates taking or exporting plants and plant products in certain situations.
- The 2008 amendments expanded the definition of a plant to include any plants (including foreign plants), and require importers of all covered plants and plant products to submit an import declaration to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) at the time of importation.
- The primary aims of the 2008 amendments were to reduce illegal logging and to increase the value of U.S. wood exports.
- Illegal logging is a pervasive problem affecting several countries, with estimates suggesting that 15% to 30% of the volume of all forestry is attributable to illegal logging, and some tropical countries reporting that between 50% and 90% of all logging is illegal.
- The economic value of global illegal logging is estimated to be between $50 billion and $100 billion of the global wood trade, and illegal logging costs governments approximately $5 billion annually in lost royalties and an additional $10 billion in lost revenue.
- The Lacey Act declaration requirements are controversial, with some contending that they are a burden and difficult to comply with, and others arguing that they are necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of the Lacey Act and serve as an oversight mechanism for compliance.
- The Lacey Act can be enforced at the border or through investigations, and violations can result in civil penalties and criminal penalties, including fines, forfeiture, and incarceration.
- The Lacey Act does not authorize funding to implement the act or enforce provisions within the act, but funding for implementing the act could come from discretionary appropriations or other accounts in federal agencies.

<summary>

- Endothelial cells were grown to confluence and stimulated with Plasminogen Activation Inhibitor-1 (PAI-1) to produce extracellular microparticles (EMPs).
- EMPs were collected, ultracentrifuged, and stored for flow cytometric analysis.
- Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to confirm EMP size and distribution.
- EMPs were introduced into an intravenous (IV) bag and circulated through a Continuous Veno-Venous Hemodialysis (CVVH) circuit.
- EMP levels were monitored during dialysis and found to decline rapidly, with 50% clearance occurring within the first 30 minutes.
- The dialysate contained 5.7% of the original EMP concentration, suggesting that EMP sequestration occurs within the filter or tubing.
- Counter-current dialysis using a standard clinical CVVH filter removes EMPs from a model patient's circulation, supporting the idea of CVVH as a therapeutic intervention for Ali.
- Limitations of the model include the saturable nature of EMP clearance, the relatively small volume of the CVVH circuit compared to human circulation, and the absence of convection and pressure gradient forces.
- Future studies could investigate more efficient and selective EMP clearance using endothelium-specific antibodies conjugated to specialty CVVH filters.

</summary>

<summary>

- The text describes the synthesis of various sulfone-substituted lactams using anhydride mannich reactions (AMRs).
- The reactions were carried out using sulfone-substituted anhydrides, which were synthesized from readily available starting materials.
- Anhydride 3a was synthesized by conjugate addition of benzenesulfinic acid sodium salt to maleic anhydride, followed by cyclization.
- Anhydrides 3b-d were synthesized by Michael addition of sulfone acetate to various tert-butyl acrylates, followed by ester cleavage and cyclization.
- The carboxylic acid intermediates were prone to decarboxylation, forming sulfone-substituted lactams as single isomers in high yields.
- The stereochemical outcome of the reactions was explained by a transition state analogous to what is operative for cyanosuccinic anhydrides.
- The carboxylic acid intermediates could be trapped with trimethylsilyldiazomethane to yield methyl esters, which could also be desulfonylated to produce the corresponding esters.
- The reaction tolerated a variety of non-enolizable aldehydes and a variety of alkylamines and anilines.
- Studies are ongoing to develop an enantioselective Michael addition with sulfone acetate to provide the anhydrides as single enantiomers.
- The AMR of sulfone-substituted anhydrides was applied to a formal synthesis of ( )-isoretronecanol, demonstrating its usefulness for the assembly of heterocyclic targets.

</summary>

<summary>

- Stroke patients often exhibit motor deficits on the contralateral side, but subtle motor deficits have been identified on the ipsilateral side as well.
- Ipsilateral motor deficits emerge during the acute phase and persist chronically.
- Clinical assessment tools may not be sufficient for detecting ipsilateral motor deficits.
- Laboratory testing has identified kinematic deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb during tasks requiring dexterity and coordination.
- Possible mechanisms for ipsilateral motor deficits include disrupted counterbalance, dysfunction of the uncrossed corticospinal track, or different roles of both sides in hemispheric functions.
- The current study aimed to investigate motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb using a tracking and reposition sense test.
- Fifty hemiparetic stroke patients and forty normal control subjects were recruited, with inclusion criteria ensuring right-handedness, no cognitive problems, and no musculoskeletal dysfunction in the unaffected upper limb.
- Tracking and joint position sense tests were conducted for the ipsilateral upper limb, with accuracy analyzed using an accuracy index and reposition errors measured.
- The study found that stroke patients had lower accuracy indices and higher error scores in the joint reposition test, with a negative correlation between motor and sensory deficits.

</summary>

• The text discusses recent studies suggesting a potential link between diabetes, insulin therapy, and increased cancer risk, specifically with the long-acting insulin analogue glargine.
• The studies reviewed include a German epidemiologic study suggesting a cancer risk associated with glargine, three commissioned studies with conflicting results, and a meta-analysis comparing cancer risk with insulin detemir. The overall evidence is inconclusive, and further research is needed to define the risk.

<summary>

- Residual and resistant microorganisms, including fungi, are the main cause of failures in root canal treatments.
- Candida albicans, a fungus with a tendency to invade dentin, is present in 20% of endodontic treatment failures.
- MTA (Mineral Trioxide Aggregate) is the gold standard for root-end filling materials due to its excellent sealing ability, biocompatibility, high alkalinity, radiopacity, antimicrobial effects, and resistance to fluid and blood contamination.
- MTA-Angelus, a variant of MTA, has good marginal adaptation, good sealing, and sealing ability in mineralized tissues with complete closure. It also has excellent antibacterial and strong fungicidal effects against C. albicans.
- In an in vitro study, the antifungal properties of fresh and set Proroot MTA and MTA-Angelus were compared against C. albicans at 1-, 24-, and 48-hour time points.
- Both Proroot MTA and MTA-Angelus were incapable of killing C. albicans after 1 hour, but they were fungicidal at 24 hours for both fresh and set samples and at both concentrations of 50 and 100 mg/ml.
- There was no significant difference in the antifungal properties of Proroot MTA and MTA-Angelus at either concentration or either time point.
- The tube-dilution susceptibility test was used to evaluate the antifungal characteristics of the materials, allowing direct contact between C. albicans and the experimental materials for a more realistic interaction.

</summary>

• The text describes a case of a 71-year-old male patient with oral submucous fibrosis and limited mouth opening who required fabrication of complete dentures. The patient underwent sectional impression procedures and hinged denture fabrication to overcome the challenge of limited oral opening.
• The text outlines the steps taken to create sectional impressions and hinged dentures, including the use of special trays, hinge assemblies, and press buttons. The text also mentions the advantages and disadvantages of this technique.
• The text also discusses other techniques and modifications for patients with restricted mouth opening, such as surgery, dynamic opening devices, and modified impression procedures. The importance of prosthodontic treatment for patients with microstomia is emphasized.
